What is XBB? The new ‘immune-evasive’ COVID strain that combines Omicron variants is driving cases in two countriesFortune10/11/2022

The XBB COVID subvariant combines Omicron strains and is driving cases in Singapore and Bangladesh.

coronavirus, omicron, xbb, xbb covid, xbb covid variant, xbb singapore, xbb.1, what is xbb, what is xbb.1, xbb.1 hong kong, new covid variant, covid news, covid variant news, us omicron booster, covid treatmentRead

rise of variants like XBB, which combine multiple COVID strains and are driving cases in countries like Singapore. </div><div data-cy="credit" class="sc-2ec4a36d-10 gdqRGr">Bryan van der Beek—Bloomberg/Getty Images</div></div></div><div class="sc-95911ed9-1 kAwtSX"><div class="sc-95911ed9-2 kLUfpm"><div id="article-content" class="sc-95911ed9-3 calDSv"><div><div data-cy="article-content" class="rawHtml-content-no-nativo"><p>New variants of the rapidly mutating coronavirus are still popping up around the world, and a new iteration of COVID on the rise in Asia may be the most immune-evasive yet. </p><div class="paywall-selector"></div><div class="paywall">



<p>The XBB strain is causing a small surge in cases in countries like Bangladesh and Singapore. The latter has recorded a daily average of about 5,500 cases over the past week, compared to a daily average of 2,000 cases a month ago.</p>



<p>Officials in Singapore, which is scaling back its <a href="https://www.scmp.com/news/asia/southeast-asia/article/3195261/singapore-ditch-rules-linked-covid-19-vaccination-status" target="_blank" aria-label="Go to https://www.scmp.com/news/asia/southeast-asia/article/3195261/singapore-ditch-rules-linked-covid-19-vaccination-status" rel="noopener" class="sc-80b85506-0 pUpMT">last remaining</a> COVID restrictions to reopen to the rest of the world, are not yet concerned about the increase in cases. On Monday, Health Minister Ong Ye Kung <a href="https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/health/15-out-of-100-people-re-infected-with-covid-19-may-be-another-wave-ong-ye-kung" target="_blank" aria-label="Go to https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/health/15-out-of-100-people-re-infected-with-covid-19-may-be-another-wave-ong-ye-kung" rel="noopener" class="sc-80b85506-0 pUpMT">noted that</a> only 15% of the country’s recent COVID cases were reinfections. “If you start to see 50% getting it a second time, you’re going to have a wave,” he said. The health ministry did start <a href="https://www.channelnewsasia.com/singapore/covid-19-bivalent-vaccine-booster-moderna-3001451" target="_blank" aria-label="Go to https://www.channelnewsasia.com/singapore/covid-19-bivalent-vaccine-booster-moderna-3001451" rel="noopener" class="sc-80b85506-0 pUpMT">doling out</a> Moderna’s Omicron booster on Tuesday, three days ahead of schedule, citing rising infections caused by the new “XBB Omicron subvariant.”</p>



<p>Hospitalizations in Singapore have <a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19/statistics" target="_blank" aria-label="Go to https://www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19/statistics" rel="noopener" class="sc-80b85506-0 pUpMT">increased alongside</a> the rise in cases, yet deaths remain low, with fewer than a dozen recorded in the country over the past week. Over 90% of Singapore’s population has received two doses of a COVID vaccine, and 79% have received at least one booster. </p>



<p>Bangladesh is also reporting a small uptick in cases, though reported numbers are smaller than Singapore’s. The South Asian country reported a daily average of about 500 cases during the week of Oct. 3, compared to an average of 300 cases a month earlier. Bangladesh has a vaccination rate of 75.5%. </p>



<p>On Monday, Hong Kong’s health authorities said they found the city’s <a href="https://news.rthk.hk/rthk/en/component/k2/1670377-20221010.htm" target="_blank" aria-label="Go to https://news.rthk.hk/rthk/en/component/k2/1670377-20221010.htm" rel="noopener" class="sc-80b85506-0 pUpMT">first case of XBB.1</a>, a subvariant of the XBB strain, in <a href="https://twitter.com/tripperhead/status/1579450340667461632" target="_blank" aria-label="Go to https://twitter.com/tripperhead/status/1579450340667461632" rel="noopener" class="sc-80b85506-0 pUpMT">an imported case</a> from the U.S. Officials said the positive case showed no symptoms.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>Immune evasive</strong></h2>



<p>Experts are paying close attention to the XBB strain, which <a href="https://fortune.com/well/2022/10/08/autumn-covid-variants-similar-omicron-convergent-evolution-recombination-deltacron-frankenvirus-fall-winter-wave-coronavirus-pandemic-epidemic/" target="_self" aria-label="Go to https://fortune.com/well/2022/10/08/autumn-covid-variants-similar-omicron-convergent-evolution-recombination-deltacron-frankenvirus-fall-winter-wave-coronavirus-pandemic-epidemic/" class="sc-80b85506-0 pUpMT">combines</a> two different Omicron strains. Eric Topol, founder of the the Scripps Research Translational Institute, <a href="https://twitter.com/EricTopol/status/1578759773146607617" target="_blank" aria-label="Go to https://twitter.com/EricTopol/status/1578759773146607617" rel="noopener" data-type="URL" data-id="https://twitter.com/EricTopol/status/1578759773146607617" class="sc-80b85506-0 pUpMT">tweeted</a> that XBB is one “of the most important variants [to] watch right now.”</p>



<figure class="wp-block-embed is-type-rich is-provider-twitter wp-block-embed-twitter"><div class="wp-block-embed__wrapper"><blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-width="500" data-dnt="true"><p lang="en" dir="ltr">The start of Singapore's XBB variant wave<br/>Notable how this variant left BA.2.3.20 in the dust, a variant with substantial growth advantage over BA.5; variant graph by <a href="https://twitter.com/JosetteSchoenma?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw" target="_blank" aria-label="Go to https://twitter.com/JosetteSchoenma?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw" rel="noopener" class="sc-80b85506-0 pUpMT">@JosetteSchoenma</a> <br/>XBB and BQ.1.1 are 2 of the most important variants on watch right now <a href="https://t.co/AvttFliZvP" target="_blank" aria-label="Go to https://t.co/AvttFliZvP" rel="noopener" class="sc-80b85506-0 pUpMT">pic.twitter.com/AvttFliZvP</a></p>— Eric Topol (@EricTopol) <a href="https://twitter.com/EricTopol/status/1578759773146607617?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw" target="_blank" aria-label="Go to https://twitter.com/EricTopol/status/1578759773146607617?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw" rel="noopener" class="sc-80b85506-0 pUpMT">October 8, 2022</a></blockquote></div></figure>



<p>The new strain is “probably the most immune-evasive yet” due to its <a href="https://twitter.com/RajlabN/status/1578796086839619584" target="_blank" aria-label="Go to https://twitter.com/RajlabN/status/1578796086839619584" rel="noopener" class="sc-80b85506-0 pUpMT">combination of mutations</a> from other strains, Raj Rajnarayanan, a professor at the New York Institute of Technology’s Jonesboro, Ark., campus, told <a href="https://fortune.com/well/2022/09/24/new-covid-omicron-variants-subvariants-evade-monoclonal-antibodies-bebtelovimab-recombinants-convergent-evolution-sars-immune-evasion/" target="_self" aria-label="Go to https://fortune.com/well/2022/09/24/new-covid-omicron-variants-subvariants-evade-monoclonal-antibodies-bebtelovimab-recombinants-convergent-evolution-sars-immune-evasion/" class="sc-80b85506-0 pUpMT"><em>Fortune</em></a> in September. A <a href="https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2022.09.15.507787v3" target="_blank" aria-label="Go to https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2022.09.15.507787v3" rel="noopener" class="sc-80b85506-0 pUpMT">preprint study</a> from Oct. 4, authored by researchers at Peking University and Changping Laboratory, found that XBB had the greatest ability to evade antibody protections among newly emerging variants. </p>



<p>Experts are also concerned that monoclonal antibody treatments might be less effective against newer variants like XBB and BA.2.75.2. “We’ve not seen this type of immune evasion before,” Michael Osterholm, director of the University of Minnesota’s Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy (CIDRAP), told <a href="https://fortune.com/well/2022/10/08/autumn-covid-variants-similar-omicron-convergent-evolution-recombination-deltacron-frankenvirus-fall-winter-wave-coronavirus-pandemic-epidemic/" target="_self" aria-label="Go to https://fortune.com/well/2022/10/08/autumn-covid-variants-similar-omicron-convergent-evolution-recombination-deltacron-frankenvirus-fall-winter-wave-coronavirus-pandemic-epidemic/" class="sc-80b85506-0 pUpMT"><em>Fortune</em></a> earlier this month.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>New variants</strong></h2>



<p>BA.5 is still the most dominant strain of COVID in the U.S., making up 79.2% of COVID cases recorded between Oct. 2 and Oct. 11, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s <a href="https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#variant-proportions" target="_blank" aria-label="Go to https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#variant-proportions" rel="noopener" data-type="URL" data-id="https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#variant-proportions" class="sc-80b85506-0 pUpMT">Nowcast</a>.</p>



<p>But other variants are starting to catch up. Over the past week, 13.6% of cases were from the <a href="https://fortune.com/2022/08/04/ba-4-6-omicron-subvariant-covid-ba-5-booster-vaccine/" target="_self" aria-label="Go to https://fortune.com/2022/08/04/ba-4-6-omicron-subvariant-covid-ba-5-booster-vaccine/" class="sc-80b85506-0 pUpMT">BA.4.6 subvariant</a>, an increase from 6.4% of cases two months ago. The <a href="https://fortune.com/well/2022/09/20/bf-7-new-covid-subvariant-rising-in-united-states-us-omicron-centaurus/" target="_self" aria-label="Go to https://fortune.com/well/2022/09/20/bf-7-new-covid-subvariant-rising-in-united-states-us-omicron-centaurus/" class="sc-80b85506-0 pUpMT">BF.7 strain</a> is also spreading quickly, making up 4.6% of cases today compared to just 0.3% two months ago.</p>



<p>In order to keep ahead of the rapidly mutating coronavirus, the U.S. approved bivalent boosters targeting the BA.4 and BA.5 subvariants on Aug. 31. Yet only 7.6 million Americans <a href="https://fortune.com/well/2022/10/09/americans-hesitant-omicron-covid-booster-shot-vaccine-coroanvirus-forecast-fall-winter/" target="_self" aria-label="Go to https://fortune.com/well/2022/10/09/americans-hesitant-omicron-covid-booster-shot-vaccine-coroanvirus-forecast-fall-winter/" class="sc-80b85506-0 pUpMT">have received</a> the Omicron booster since it became widely available on Labor Day. A survey from the Kaiser Family Foundation found that two-thirds of Americans are either putting off getting the new booster or saying they won’t get it at all.</p></div><div class="sc-83cd12c6-0 variants of the rapidly mutating coronavirus are still popping up around the world, and a new iteration of COVID on the rise in Asia may be the most immune-evasive yet. \u003c/p\u003e\u003cdiv class=\"paywall-selector\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003cdiv class=\"paywall\"\u003e\n\n\n\n\u003cp\u003eThe XBB strain is causing a small surge in cases in countries like Bangladesh and Singapore. The latter has recorded a daily average of about 5,500 cases over the past week, compared to a daily average of 2,000 cases a month ago.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\n\n\u003cp\u003eOfficials in Singapore, which is scaling back its \u003ca href=\"https://www.scmp.com/news/asia/southeast-asia/article/3195261/singapore-ditch-rules-linked-covid-19-vaccination-status\"\u003elast remaining\u003c/a\u003e COVID restrictions to reopen to the rest of the world, are not yet concerned about the increase in cases. On Monday, Health Minister Ong Ye Kung \u003ca href=\"https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/health/15-out-of-100-people-re-infected-with-covid-19-may-be-another-wave-ong-ye-kung\"\u003enoted that\u003c/a\u003e only 15% of the country\u0026#8217;s recent COVID cases were reinfections. \u0026#8220;If you start to see 50% getting it a second time, you\u0026#8217;re going to have a wave,” he said.\u0026nbsp;The health ministry did start \u003ca href=\"https://www.channelnewsasia.com/singapore/covid-19-bivalent-vaccine-booster-moderna-3001451\"\u003edoling out\u003c/a\u003e Moderna\u0026#8217;s Omicron booster on Tuesday, three days ahead of schedule, citing rising infections caused by the new \u0026#8220;XBB Omicron subvariant.\u0026#8221;\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\n\n\u003cp\u003eHospitalizations in Singapore have \u003ca href=\"https://www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19/statistics\"\u003eincreased alongside\u003c/a\u003e the rise in cases, yet deaths remain low, with fewer than a dozen recorded in the country over the past week. Over 90% of Singapore\u0026#8217;s population has received two doses of a COVID vaccine, and 79% have received at least one booster. \u003c/p\u003e\n\n\n\n\u003cp\u003eBangladesh is also reporting a small uptick in cases, though reported numbers are smaller than Singapore\u0026#8217;s. The South Asian country reported a daily average of about 500 cases during the week of Oct. 3, compared to an average of 300 cases a month earlier. Bangladesh has a vaccination rate of 75.5%. \u003c/p\u003e\n\n\n\n\u003cp\u003eOn Monday, Hong Kong’s health authorities said they found the city’s \u003ca href=\"https://news.rthk.hk/rthk/en/component/k2/1670377-20221010.htm\"\u003efirst case of XBB.1\u003c/a\u003e, a subvariant of the XBB strain, in \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/tripperhead/status/1579450340667461632\"\u003ean imported case\u003c/a\u003e from the U.S. Officials said the positive case showed no symptoms.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\n\n\u003ch2 class=\"wp-block-heading\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eImmune evasive\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n\n\n\u003cp\u003eExperts are paying close attention to the XBB strain, which \u003ca href=\"https://fortune.com/well/2022/10/08/autumn-covid-variants-similar-omicron-convergent-evolution-recombination-deltacron-frankenvirus-fall-winter-wave-coronavirus-pandemic-epidemic/\"\u003ecombines\u003c/a\u003e two different Omicron strains. Eric Topol, founder of the the Scripps Research Translational Institute, \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/EricTopol/status/1578759773146607617\" data-type=\"URL\" data-id=\"https://twitter.com/EricTopol/status/1578759773146607617\"\u003etweeted\u003c/a\u003e that XBB is one “of the most important variants [to] watch right now.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\n\n\u003cfigure class=\"wp-block-embed is-type-rich is-provider-twitter wp-block-embed-twitter\"\u003e\u003cdiv class=\"wp-block-embed__wrapper\"\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\" data-dnt=\"true\"\u003e\u003cp lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\"\u003eThe start of Singapore\u0026#39;s XBB variant wave\u003cbr\u003eNotable how this variant left BA.2.3.20 in the dust, a variant with substantial growth advantage over BA.5; variant graph by \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/JosetteSchoenma?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\"\u003e@JosetteSchoenma\u003c/a\u003e \u003cbr\u003eXBB and BQ.1.1 are 2 of the most important variants on watch right now \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/AvttFliZvP\"\u003epic.twitter.com/AvttFliZvP\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u0026mdash; Eric Topol (@EricTopol) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/EricTopol/status/1578759773146607617?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\"\u003eOctober 8, 2022\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/blockquote\u003e\u003cscript async src=\"https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"\u003e\u003c/script\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\n\n\n\u003cp\u003eThe new strain is “probably the most immune-evasive yet” due to its \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/RajlabN/status/1578796086839619584\"\u003ecombination of mutations\u003c/a\u003e from other strains, Raj Rajnarayanan, a professor at the New York Institute of Technology’s Jonesboro, Ark., campus, told \u003ca href=\"https://fortune.com/well/2022/09/24/new-covid-omicron-variants-subvariants-evade-monoclonal-antibodies-bebtelovimab-recombinants-convergent-evolution-sars-immune-evasion/\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eFortune\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e in September. A \u003ca href=\"https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2022.09.15.507787v3\"\u003epreprint study\u003c/a\u003e from Oct. 4, authored by researchers at Peking University and Changping Laboratory, found that XBB had the greatest ability to evade antibody protections among newly emerging variants. \u003c/p\u003e\n\n\n\n\u003cp\u003eExperts are also concerned that monoclonal antibody treatments might be less effective against newer variants like XBB and BA.2.75.2.\u0026nbsp;“We’ve not seen this type of immune evasion before,” Michael Osterholm, director of the University of Minnesota’s Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy (CIDRAP), told \u003ca href=\"https://fortune.com/well/2022/10/08/autumn-covid-variants-similar-omicron-convergent-evolution-recombination-deltacron-frankenvirus-fall-winter-wave-coronavirus-pandemic-epidemic/\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eFortune\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e earlier this month.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\n\n\u003ch2 class=\"wp-block-heading\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eNew variants\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n\n\n\u003cp\u003eBA.5 is still the most dominant strain of COVID in the U.S., making up 79.2% of COVID cases recorded between Oct. 2 and Oct. 11, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s \u003ca href=\"https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#variant-proportions\" data-type=\"URL\" data-id=\"https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#variant-proportions\"\u003eNowcast\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\n\n\u003cp\u003eBut other variants are starting to catch up. Over the past week, 13.6% of cases were from the \u003ca href=\"https://fortune.com/2022/08/04/ba-4-6-omicron-subvariant-covid-ba-5-booster-vaccine/\"\u003eBA.4.6 subvariant\u003c/a\u003e, an increase from 6.4% of cases two months ago.\u0026nbsp;The \u003ca href=\"https://fortune.com/well/2022/09/20/bf-7-new-covid-subvariant-rising-in-united-states-us-omicron-centaurus/\"\u003eBF.7 strain\u003c/a\u003e is also spreading quickly, making up 4.6% of cases today compared to just 0.3% two months ago.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\n\n\u003cp\u003eIn order to keep ahead of the rapidly mutating coronavirus, the U.S. approved bivalent boosters targeting the BA.4 and BA.5 subvariants on Aug. 31. Yet only 7.6 million Americans \u003ca href=\"https://fortune.com/well/2022/10/09/americans-hesitant-omicron-covid-booster-shot-vaccine-coroanvirus-forecast-fall-winter/\"\u003ehave received\u003c/a\u003e the Omicron booster since it became widely available on Labor Day. A survey from the Kaiser Family Foundation found that two-thirds of Americans are either putting off getting the new booster or saying they won’t get it at all.\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e","databaseId":3390059,"dateGmt":"2022-10-11T08:51:06","dek":"","description":"The XBB COVID subvariant combines Omicron strains and is driving cases in Singapore and Bangladesh.","faq":[],"featuredMediaType":"image","floatingNavContent":"","floatingNavTitle":"","id":"cG9zdDozMzkwMDU5","image":"https://fortune.com/img-assets/wp-content/uploads/2022/10/GettyImages-1240244050-e1665462446353.jpeg?resize=1200,600","imageCaption":"Experts are studying the rise of variants like XBB, which combine multiple COVID strains and are driving cases in countries like Singapore. Over 90% of Singapore\u0026#8217;s population has received two doses of a COVID vaccine, and 79% have received at least one booster. \u003c/p\u003e\n\n\n\n\u003cp\u003eBangladesh is also reporting a small uptick in cases, though reported numbers are smaller than Singapore\u0026#8217;s. The South Asian country reported a daily average of about 500 cases during the week of Oct. 3, compared to an average of 300 cases a month earlier. Bangladesh has a vaccination rate of 75.5%. \u003c/p\u003e\n\n\n\n\u003cp\u003eOn Monday, Hong Kong’s health authorities said they found the city’s \u003ca href=\"https://news.rthk.hk/rthk/en/component/k2/1670377-20221010.htm\"\u003efirst case of XBB.1\u003c/a\u003e, a subvariant of the XBB strain, in \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/tripperhead/status/1579450340667461632\"\u003ean imported case\u003c/a\u003e from the U.S. Officials said the positive case showed no symptoms.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\n\n\u003ch2 class=\"wp-block-heading\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eImmune evasive\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n\n\n\u003cp\u003eExperts are paying close attention to the XBB strain, which \u003ca href=\"https://fortune.com/well/2022/10/08/autumn-covid-variants-similar-omicron-convergent-evolution-recombination-deltacron-frankenvirus-fall-winter-wave-coronavirus-pandemic-epidemic/\"\u003ecombines\u003c/a\u003e two different Omicron strains. Eric Topol, founder of the the Scripps Research Translational Institute, \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/EricTopol/status/1578759773146607617\" data-type=\"URL\" data-id=\"https://twitter.com/EricTopol/status/1578759773146607617\"\u003etweeted\u003c/a\u003e that XBB is one “of the most important variants [to] watch right now.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\n\n\u003cfigure class=\"wp-block-embed is-type-rich is-provider-twitter wp-block-embed-twitter\"\u003e\u003cdiv class=\"wp-block-embed__wrapper\"\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"500\" data-dnt=\"true\"\u003e\u003cp lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\"\u003eThe start of Singapore\u0026#39;s XBB variant wave\u003cbr\u003eNotable how this variant left BA.2.3.20 in the dust, a variant with substantial growth advantage over BA.5; variant graph by \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/JosetteSchoenma?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\"\u003e@JosetteSchoenma\u003c/a\u003e \u003cbr\u003eXBB and BQ.1.1 are 2 of the most important variants on watch right now \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/AvttFliZvP\"\u003epic.twitter.com/AvttFliZvP\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u0026mdash; Eric Topol (@EricTopol) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/EricTopol/status/1578759773146607617?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\"\u003eOctober 8, 2022\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/blockquote\u003e\u003cscript async src=\"https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"\u003e\u003c/script\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\n\n\n\u003cp\u003eThe new strain is “probably the most immune-evasive yet” due to its \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/RajlabN/status/1578796086839619584\"\u003ecombination of mutations\u003c/a\u003e from other strains, Raj Rajnarayanan, a professor at the New York Institute of Technology’s Jonesboro, Ark., campus, told \u003ca href=\"https://fortune.com/well/2022/09/24/new-covid-omicron-variants-subvariants-evade-monoclonal-antibodies-bebtelovimab-recombinants-convergent-evolution-sars-immune-evasion/\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eFortune\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e in September. A \u003ca href=\"https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2022.09.15.507787v3\"\u003epreprint study\u003c/a\u003e from Oct. 4, authored by researchers at Peking University and Changping Laboratory, found that XBB had the greatest ability to evade antibody protections among newly emerging variants. \u003c/p\u003e\n\n\n\n\u003cp\u003eExperts are also concerned that monoclonal antibody treatments might be less effective against newer variants like XBB and BA.2.75.2.\u0026nbsp;“We’ve not seen this type of immune evasion before,” Michael Osterholm, director of the University of Minnesota’s Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy (CIDRAP), told \u003ca href=\"https://fortune.com/well/2022/10/08/autumn-covid-variants-similar-omicron-convergent-evolution-recombination-deltacron-frankenvirus-fall-winter-wave-coronavirus-pandemic-epidemic/\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eFortune\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e earlier this month.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\n\n\u003ch2 class=\"wp-block-heading\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eNew variants\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n\n\n\u003cp\u003eBA.5 is still the most dominant strain of COVID in the U.S., making up 79.2% of COVID cases recorded between Oct. 2 and Oct. 11, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s \u003ca href=\"https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#variant-proportions\" data-type=\"URL\" data-id=\"https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#variant-proportions\"\u003eNowcast\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\n\n\u003cp\u003eBut other variants are starting to catch up. Over the past week, 13.6% of cases were from the \u003ca href=\"https://fortune.com/2022/08/04/ba-4-6-omicron-subvariant-covid-ba-5-booster-vaccine/\"\u003eBA.4.6 subvariant\u003c/a\u003e, an increase from 6.4% of cases two months ago.\u0026nbsp;The \u003ca href=\"https://fortune.com/well/2022/09/20/bf-7-new-covid-subvariant-rising-in-united-states-us-omicron-centaurus/\"\u003eBF.7 strain\u003c/a\u003e is also spreading quickly, making up 4.6% of cases today compared to just 0.3% two months ago.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\n\n\u003cp\u003eIn order to keep ahead of the rapidly mutating coronavirus, the U.S. approved bivalent boosters targeting the BA.4 and BA.5 subvariants on Aug. 31. Yet only 7.6 million Americans \u003ca href=\"https://fortune.com/well/2022/10/09/americans-hesitant-omicron-covid-booster-shot-vaccine-coroanvirus-forecast-fall-winter/\"\u003ehave received\u003c/a\u003e the Omicron booster since it became widely available on Labor Day. readabilityObject.title: What is XBB? A new COVID strain is driving cases in two countries and worrying scientists
readabilityObject.content:
New variants of the rapidly mutating coronavirus are still popping up around the world, and a new iteration of COVID on the rise in Asia may be the most immune-evasive yet.

The XBB strain is causing a small surge in cases in countries like Bangladesh and Singapore. The latter has recorded a daily average of about 5,500 cases over the past week, compared to a daily average of 2,000 cases a month ago.

Officials in Singapore, which is scaling back its last remaining COVID restrictions to reopen to the rest of the world, are not yet concerned about the increase in cases. On Monday, Health Minister Ong Ye Kung noted that only 15% of the country’s recent COVID cases were reinfections. “If you start to see 50% getting it a second time, you’re going to have a wave,” he said. The health ministry did start doling out Moderna’s Omicron booster on Tuesday, three days ahead of schedule, citing rising infections caused by the new “XBB Omicron subvariant.”

Hospitalizations in Singapore have increased alongside the rise in cases, yet deaths remain low, with fewer than a dozen recorded in the country over the past week. Over 90% of Singapore’s population has received two doses of a COVID vaccine, and 79% have received at least one booster.

Bangladesh is also reporting a small uptick in cases, though reported numbers are smaller than Singapore’s. The South Asian country reported a daily average of about 500 cases during the week of Oct. 3, compared to an average of 300 cases a month earlier. Bangladesh has a vaccination rate of 75.5%.

On Monday, Hong Kong’s health authorities said they found the city’s first case of XBB.1, a subvariant of the XBB strain, in an imported case from the U.S. Officials said the positive case showed no symptoms.

Immune evasive

Experts are paying close attention to the XBB strain, which combines two different Omicron strains. Eric Topol, founder of the the Scripps Research Translational Institute, tweeted that XBB is one “of the most important variants [to] watch right now.”

The new strain is “probably the most immune-evasive yet” due to its combination of mutations from other strains, Raj Rajnarayanan, a professor at the New York Institute of Technology’s Jonesboro, Ark., campus, told Fortune in September. A preprint study from Oct. 4, authored by researchers at Peking University and Changping Laboratory, found that XBB had the greatest ability to evade antibody protections among newly emerging variants.

Experts are also concerned that monoclonal antibody treatments might be less effective against newer variants like XBB and BA.2.75.2. “We’ve not seen this type of immune evasion before,” Michael Osterholm, director of the University of Minnesota’s Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy (CIDRAP), told Fortune earlier this month.

New variants

BA.5 is still the most dominant strain of COVID in the U.S., making up 79.2% of COVID cases recorded between Oct. 2 and Oct. 11, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s Nowcast.

But other variants are starting to catch up. Over the past week, 13.6% of cases were from the BA.4.6 subvariant, an increase from 6.4% of cases two months ago. The BF.7 strain is also spreading quickly, making up 4.6% of cases today compared to just 0.3% two months ago.

In order to keep ahead of the rapidly mutating coronavirus, the U.S. approved bivalent boosters targeting the BA.4 and BA.5 subvariants on Aug. 31. Yet only 7.6 million Americans have received the Omicron booster since it became widely available on Labor Day. A survey from the Kaiser Family Foundation found that two-thirds of Americans are either putting off getting the new booster or saying they won’t get it at all.
